linkTarget.anchoringText: Geochemical techniques can be used to quantitatively determine the contribution of each of several zones to a commingled oil (or gas) stream (after McCaffrey et al. 2011). The present study describes one particularly useful application of this technique to multilateral wells: identification of sanded-out intervals for FCO. This study shows three examples where this technique was applied in the West Sak field on the North Slope of Alaska (Fig. 1),

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Location map for the North Slope of Alaska

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location map for the North Slope of Alaska

linkTarget.anchoringText: West Sak is a biodegraded oil accumulation reservoired between 2,400 and 3,800 ft subsea in cool (75Â°F) Upper Cretaceous marine sandstones of the Schrader Bluff Formation (Werner 1987). Production is primarily from the West Sak D, B and A sands. A type log is provided as Fig. 2 for illustration of the geologic complexity. The reservoirs consist of very fine-grained, poorly consolidated sand with permeabilities varying from 20 to 3000 md.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: A typical type log sand sequence for West Sak

formatted-caption.caption-text: A typical type log sand sequence for West Sak

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 3 shows examples of the GC fingerprints of end member oils from each of the three reservoirs in the West Sak field. Oils from each zone have a unique fingerprint.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Examples of GC fingerprints of oil samples from the West Sak A, B, and D sands Example of "A Sand" Oil GC Fingerprint Example of "B Sand" Oil GC Fingerprint Example of "D Sand" Oil GC Fingerprint

formatted-caption.caption-text: Examples of GC fingerprints of oil samples from the West Sak A, B, and D sands Example of "A Sand" Oil GC Fingerprint Example of "B Sand" Oil GC Fingerprint Example of "D Sand" Oil GC Fingerprint

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Example of "A Sand" Oil GC Fingerprint
Example of "B Sand" Oil GC Fingerprint
Example of "D Sand" Oil GC Fingerprint

linkTarget.anchoringText: Well X is a trilateral well (mainbore plus two laterals, see Fig. 4) completed in the A, B, and D sands of the West Sak field. Total oil production from Well X fell in October 2012. Geochemical allocation of commingled production from that well indicated that the contribution of the B sand fell with overall production rate.

Based on that observation, an FCO of the B Sand was conducted resulting in approximately 200 BOPD incremental oil production from the well (Fig. 5). Samples analyzed after the FCO operation indicated that the B sand had been returned to production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Well test oil rate and sand allocations with time for Well X

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well test oil rate and sand allocations with time for Well X

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on that observation, a FCO of the A Sand was conducted resulting in approximately 500 BOPD incremental oil production from the well (Fig. 6). Samples analyzed after the FCO operation indicated that the A sand had been returned to production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Well test oil rate and sand allocations with time for Well Y

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well test oil rate and sand allocations with time for Well Y

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on that observation, a FCO of the A Sand was conducted resulting in approximately 400 BOPD incremental oil production from the well (Fig. 7). Samples analyzed after the FCO operation indicated that the A sand had been returned to production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Well test oil rate and sand allocations with time for Well Z

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well test oil rate and sand allocations with time for Well Z
